Award.AbstractNarration:
The 2019 Seminar on Stochastic Processes (SSP) will be held at the University of Utah in Salt Lake City, UT from March 13-16, 2019. This conference has been held annually since 1981 and is devoted to probability theory and stochastic processes. Past conferences have had major impact on the field in several distinct ways. They consistently feature broad participation of graduate students and early-career researchers, including future Fields medalists and other world-leading experts in the early stages of their research careers. The primary goal is to provide a platform for the dissemination of the most significant recent research progress in the theory of stochastic processes, and to enable participants to discuss ideas in an informal atmosphere.

Stochastic processes are basic building blocks of the way that randomness exhibits itself in the real world, and are used to model a wide range of physical, biological, ecological, and financial phenomena. The format of this meeting is based on the success of recent Seminars on Stochastic Processes. There will be five one hour talks and a tutorial session consisting of two 90 minute lectures, all delivered by distinguished speakers on key recent themes and developments in stochastic processes research. Talks also emphasize the important connections of stochastic processes to other parts of mathematics and the sciences. There will also be a poster session and opportunities for early career researchers to present their own research, and time set aside for the discussion of open problems.

More details are available at the conference website

http://www.math.utah.edu/SSP-2019/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Seminar on Stochastic Processes 2019 was a four day conference held from March 13-16, 2019, at the University of Utah in Salt Lake City. Its main purpose was to bring together leading regional and national researchers in probability theory and its applications, especially beginning researchers and graduate students, to foster interaction and stimulate research activity. 

The conference featured five plenary speakers who presented research at the forefront of probability theory and its applications. Topics included stochastic partial differential equations, probabilistic aspects of mean curvature flow, random growth processes, probabilistic models of Bose-Einstein condensation, and applications of probability theory to biological processes. The conference also featured a day long tutorial session on extremal values of local time fields for random walks, a current hot topic of research. A poster session was also included for beginning researchers to present their latest research. Junior participants also had the opportunity to expand their network of potential collaborators and mentors. A total of 97 people attended the conference over the four days.

SSP 2019 was the latest in a long running series of annual conferences devoted to stochastic analysis, Markov processes, and other topics in probability theory of current interest. The 2020 conference will be held in Michigan State University in Lansing, Michigan.
